image.altText: An aerial view of a retirement village surrounded by a body of water. The buildings have matching grey rooves.

props.synopsis: Retirement villages are governed by a patchwork of laws that differ from state to state but advocates want tougher regulation of the sector. Could treating the sector like a "financial product" be the answer, and how would it work?

title.children: Should retirement villages be treated like 'financial products'?

image.altText: a close up picture of a green Wasabi plant growing in Tasmania

props.synopsis: Did you know that most of the wasabi you put on your sushi is actually horseradish, with a little bit of wasabi in it? The Tasmanian Country Hour visited Australia's only commercial crop, grown inside a greenhouse in north-west Tasmania.Â

title.children: ðŸ“£ Planned expansion at Wasabi farm in north-west Tasmania

image.altText: Smoke emerges from the top of a large white and red cruise ship at night with lights reflected in water below.

props.synopsis:
Business owners and travellers are facing extensive wait times to get large vehicles onto the Spirit of Tasmania, with one local business owner scaling down her pet transport service due to ongoing vehicle booking shortages.

Â

title.children: Travellers and businesses face months-long wait for Spirit bookings, but new ships won't be operational until 2026

image.altText: Artist impression of proposed waterside development in Hobart.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence (AI) was used by the Tasmanian government to validate a developer's claim about the economic benefits of a contentious luxury hotel planned for Hobart, new documents reveal.

title.children: 'Cooking the books': Tasmanian government used AI to validate developer's hotel claims

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff speaking at a lecturn, with Guy Barnett standing next to him.

props.synopsis: The demise of Michael Ferguson could be a word of warning to other ministers. And the new cabinet is full of faces that have fallen foul of the opposition and crossbench in the past.

title.children: A major shift has happened since Tasmania's last election: Instant accountability for ministers

image.altText: Three women standing in front of a tree.

props.synopsis: More than 50 years on, Robyn Cohen still lives with the pain of having had her baby forcibly given up for adoption. She's one of a number of Tasmanian women affected by the practice who are fighting for compensation.

title.children: 'Finally, we have a voice': Victims of forced adoption practices continue push for compensation

image.altText: An older woman in a grey knitted jumper and an older man in a green flannelette shirt stands in their Earthship.

props.synopsis: Immune to power outages, the couple generate their own electricity using solar panels, and only use an estimated 2 kWh per day.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ State's recent power outages highlight benefits of living off-grid

props.synopsis:
Politicians on both sides of parliament attack Lidia Thorpe's disruption of a ceremony for King Charles. But on Q+A, one Indigenous man urged them to listen.

Â 

Â

title.children: 'What do we have left?' Indigenous plea to listen to Lidia Thorpe

image.altText: A microchip.

props.synopsis: Silicon chips are now fundamental to modern life, incorporated into every facet of electronics and driving up share prices on Wall Street. Taiwan has dominated semiconductor production but finds itself at the centre of a geopolitical, and technological, contest.

title.children: Taiwan's chip domination the real prize in East-West divide

image.altText: Jill Stein speaks at a podium.

props.synopsis: The Biden administration's staunch support of Israel was already threatening the Democrats' support from Arab-Americans in the key battleground state of Michigan, but for some in the community the escalating situation in Lebanon is the final straw.

title.children: In one attack ad, Jill Stein's face morphs into Donald Trump. This is why she's a target

image.altText: Peter Dutton wears glasses and looks up while sitting in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The differences between Labor and the Coalition's plans to ease the housing crisis are becoming clearer, with the opposition betting that Australians prefer detached dwellings in outer suburbs rather than high-density housing.Â

title.children: The opposition is betting on detached homes in outer suburbs as the election fight over housing policies shapes up

image.altText: A Qantas worker wearing a high-vis vest wipes down an engine that has a red kangaroo logo on it.

props.synopsis: After Qantas was ordered by the Federal Court to compensate 1,700 former workers, an industrial relations lawyer says the airline will still have saved millions of dollars once it pays its legal bills, ex-employees, and any extra penalties.

title.children: Qantas saved $580m by sacking hundreds of ground crew. They won't get anything close to that in compensation

image.altText: A view of a harbour in Jeju Island in South Korea

props.synopsis: The South Korean island of Jeju is offering newlyweds the chance to rent apartments for less than $30 a month in the hope it might encourage them to have children.

title.children: South Korean tourism island offers rent for $28 a month to boost fertility rates

image.altText: Emissions are seen from a factory at Broadwater in far northern New South Wales.

props.synopsis: The federal government may push back the release of its 2035 emissions reduction target from early next year.

title.children: Australia's next big climate target might be delayed by months

image.altText: A man in a black t-shirt and cap stands behind a bar with bottles of alcohol all around him

props.synopsis: Darren Brown says he has gone to "every length" to get the hotel he runs properly listed on Google, and that without the visibility the losses to the business have been "immeasurable".

title.children: 'Basically invisible': Pub's lengthy battle to be listed on Google

image.altText: Moldova's President Maia Sandu casts her vote during Moldova's presidential election and EU referendum.

props.synopsis: Moldovans have voted by a razor-thin majority in favour of securing the country's path toward European Union membership, electoral data shows.Â

title.children: Moldova narrowly votes for EU membership amid claims of 'unprecedented' Russian interference

image.altText: An illustration of a child walking into a school, wearing a backpack and blue t-shirt.

props.synopsis: Child abuse prevention researchers say the "huge" problem of child-on-child sex abuse within Australian schools is growing. It's sparked urgent calls to overhaul the curriculum on porn and consent.

title.children: Researchers fear child-on-child sex abuse is becoming a 'huge' problem

image.altText: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump looking at each other in election illustration

props.synopsis: Kamala Harris celebrates her 60th birthday with a day of campaigning as Donald Trump reveals details of a conversation with Benjamin Netanyahu â€” here's the latest updates from the US election.

title.children: Trump's McDonald's shift and Stevie Wonder serenades Kamala Harris â€” the latest from the US election campaign

image.altText: Two boys sit on a makeshift white scrap of sheet in front of a port.

props.synopsis: Escalating militant attacks on Chinese investments threaten China's Belt and Road initiative in Pakistan as security concerns dominate talks between the two countries.Â

title.children: China's 'Silk Road' ambitions threatened by militant attacks

image.altText: A woman in red swimsuit

props.synopsis: An Italian surfer has died in a rare and tragic accident after being struck by a swordfish while surfing off Indonesia's West Sumatra coast.

title.children: Surfer dies in freak swordfish accident while catching wave off west coast of Sumatra

image.altText: Yael Stone sits looking straight with a neutral expression while Jack Manning Bancroft wears a hat backwards, holding a mug

props.synopsis: She turned her back on Hollywood. He collapsed from exhaustion. Unconventional couple Yael Stone and Jack Manning Bancroft reveal the sacrifices they make to live by their convictions.

title.children: When actor Yael Stone walked away from Hollywood, everyone thought she was crazy â€” except the man who loved her

image.altText: A woman and man with sunglasses.

props.synopsis: It was alleged two boys â€” who cannot be identified as they were 17 years old at the time â€” broke into the Lovell's house on Boxing Day night in 2022.

title.children: Husband of Brisbane woman killed during home invasion didn't realise he had also been stabbed, court hears

image.altText: A wrinkly cat sits on a lap

props.synopsis: The XL Bully cat, a crossbreed of Sphynx cats and Munchkin cats, is causing global concern due to its rising popularity.Â

title.children: 'An animal welfare disaster': The designer cat breed causing international concern

image.altText: An elderly man wearing a blue shirt and dark suit jacket stands next to a painting with calligraphic text

props.synopsis: Influential cleric Fethullah GÃ¼len, known for starting the faith movement Hizmet in 1969 and blamed for a failed coup against Turkish leader ErdoÄŸan, dies in the US aged 83.

title.children: Fethullah GÃ¼len, cleric accused of 2016 TÃ¼rkiye coup attempt, dies aged 83

image.altText: Westpac, St George and CommBank apps on an iPhone screen.

props.synopsis: Thousands of bank customers were affected by Westpac and St George app and internet bank outages and a Commonwealth Bank duplicate transaction error, leading a finance expert to advise Australians to bank with at least two different institutions to mitigate risk.

title.children: Banks give people access to their own money. What happens when they don't work?

image.altText: A general shot of work taking place at a mine site.

props.synopsis: Companies have been charged over the deaths of workers in separate incidents in the Pilbara and the Goldfields in 2022.

title.children: Worksafe to prosecute mining companies after deaths at WA sites just days apart

image.altText: a close-up of a person holding a glass under a running tap, filling it with water

props.synopsis: The National Health and Medical Research Council has released draft guidelines on limits for four types of "forever chemicals" in drinking water. So how do they compare with other countries such as the US?

title.children: Draft limits of PFAS in Australia's drinking water released by national medical research body

image.altText: Qantas planes sit parked at Sydney Airport, with the city's skyline in the background.

props.synopsis: Qantas is facing a multi-million-dollar compensation bill after it illegally sacked hundreds of workers during the COVID-19 pandemic, with the Federal Court ordering three former employees will receive a share of $170,000.

title.children: 'This is the spirit of Australia': Sacked Qantas workers rejoice as airline faces multi-million-dollar compensation bill

image.altText: cars on the road at sunset

props.synopsis: Toll roads are a part of life for many Australians, but the fees to drive on them, and the fines for not paying, are pushing motorists to the edge. These suburbs are feeling the pinch more than others.

title.children: Five graphs and maps that show the cost of tolls on Australian drivers

image.altText: brown monkey swings in cage black

props.synopsis: Eleven monkeys have died over the past week, with a further two dying over the weekend. Authorities say the bacterial infection melioidosis killed at least nine of the monkeys at Hong Kong's oldest zoo.Â

title.children: Soil infection kills at least nine monkeys at a Hong Kong zoo, authorities say

image.altText: A low shot looking up at a sign on the side of Perth Children's Hospital.

props.synopsis: A Perth couple are on trial accused of starving their teenage daughter to the point she weighed barely more than 27 kilograms and was at risk of having a heart attack.

title.children: Court hears Perth teenager weighed just 27 kilograms as parents face trial over her malnutrition

image.altText: A black-and-white photo of a young boy leaning on the railing of a rodeo arena.

props.synopsis: The cost of living and a downturn in ticket sales have led to the collapse of the board that runs the famed Mount Isa rodeo.

title.children: Cost of living blamed as largest rodeo in the southern hemisphere enters voluntary administration

image.altText: A young brunette girl with glasses on holds a yellow flower

props.synopsis: Jenni Matters had anorexia nervosa for two years before taking her own life. Before her death, a nurse told the young woman she was "so skinny" and asked her for diet advice.

title.children: Nurse asked anorexia patient for diet tips, inquest hears

image.altText: People walking across a courtyard surrounded by buildings.

props.synopsis: Vice-chancellor Stephen Parker says the University of Canberra is "spending beyond its means" and needs to save about $50 million in recurrent expenditure by the end of next year.Â

title.children: University of Canberra to cut 200 jobs as part of 'urgent and significant' cost-saving measures
